rev.diff:
Line 295: Line 295:
During the night of 5â6 February, some protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, and Alexandria had peaceful late-night protests. However, [[gunshot|gunfire]] was heard in the early hours of the day in Cairo.<ref name="aljazlive"/> The same organisers of the "Day of Anger", "Friday of Anger", "March of the Millions" and "Friday of Departure" called for a protest in what was dubbed the "'''Sunday of Martyrs'''" ({{lang-ar|Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¡}}).{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
During the night of 5â6 February, some protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, and Alexandria had peaceful late-night protests. However, [[gunshot|gunfire]] was heard in the early hours of the day in Cairo.<ref name="aljazlive"/> The same organisers of the "Day of Anger", "Friday of Anger", "March of the Millions" and "Friday of Departure" called for a protest in what was dubbed the "'''Sunday of Martyrs'''" ({{lang-ar|Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¡}}).{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
â
Egyptian Christians held mass in Tahrir Square in Cairo in order to counter claims by state television that most of the anti-Mubarak protesters are members of the Muslim Brotherhood. Copts wanted to show that they are a part of Egypt's popular uprising and share the same grievances as the rest of the country. Christians started their Sunday Mass in Cairo's Tahrir Square as Muslim protesters formed a ring around them to protect them during the service.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} Muslims later participated in ''[[Salat al-Janazah]]'' ({{lang-ar|'''ØµÙØ§Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø²Ø©'''}}) (literally: funeral prayer).{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} There were also demonstrations continuing in Alexandria focuses around the central train stations.{{Which?|date=February 2011}}<ref name="aljazlive"/>
+
Egyptian Christians held mass in Tahrir Square in Cairo in order to counter claims by state television that most of the anti-Mubarak protesters are members of the Muslim Brotherhood. Copts wanted to show that they are a part of Egypt's popular uprising and share the same grievances as the rest of the country. Christians started their Sunday Mass in Cairo's Tahrir Square as Muslim protesters formed a ring around them to protect them during the service.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onislam.net/english/news/africa/450890-egypt-christians-muslims-unite-in-tahrir.html|title=Egypt Christians, Muslims Unite in Tahrir|publisher=On Islam|accessdate=06 February 2011}}</ref> Muslims later participated in ''[[Salat al-Janazah]]'' ({{lang-ar|'''ØµÙØ§Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø²Ø©'''}}) (literally: funeral prayer).{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} There were also demonstrations continuing in Alexandria focuses around the central train stations.{{Which?|date=February 2011}}<ref name="aljazlive"/>
On Sunday, journalists continued to be targets. [[Ayman Mohyeldin]], an ''Al Jazeera English'' journalist, was arrested by soldiers on Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/05/live-blog-feb-6-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 6 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> ''Al Jazeera'' called for his immediate release.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
On Sunday, journalists continued to be targets. [[Ayman Mohyeldin]], an ''Al Jazeera English'' journalist, was arrested by soldiers on Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/05/live-blog-feb-6-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 6 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> ''Al Jazeera'' called for his immediate release.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
